case_name: Mode Narain, Hari Narain and Rajballav Narain v. Bijendra Narain

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 756 of 1964 is an appeal from the judgment and decree dated November 19, 1957 of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 258 of 1848.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 756 of 1964. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated November 19, 1957 of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 258 of 1848.

facts.text: Suit No. 17 of 1942 was filed by Bijendra Narain son of Ishwari Narain against Mode Narain, Hari Narain and Rajballav Narain, sons of Bidya Narain, and others for partition and separate possession of a half share in properties in schedules A, B, C.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal with certificate under Art. 133  1  a  of the Constitution arises out of suit No. 17 of 1942 of the file of Subordinate Judge, Purnea, filed by Bijendra Narain son of Ishwari Narain against Mode Narain, Hari Narain and Rajballav Narain, sons of Bidya Narain, and others for a decree for partition and separate possession of a half share in the properties described in schedules A, B C to the plaint.

facts.text: The suit No. 17 of 1942 was decreed by the Trial Court (Subordinate Judge, Purnea) and confirmed by Patna High Court with slight modification.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was decreed by the Trial Court and in appeal to the High Court of Judicature at Patna the decree was companyfirmed with a slight modification. The defendants in the suit have appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Mankishun had four sons: Talebar, Indra Narain, Chandra Narain and Shyam Narain.

anchor.surface_text: One Mankishun had four sons Talebar, Indra Narain, Chandra Narain and Shyam Narain. Talebar had two sons Hanuman and Raghu Nandan.

facts.text: Talebar had two sons Hanuman and Raghu Nandan. Hanuman died leaving no lineal descendant. Raghu Nandan adopted Udit Narain, grandson of his uncle Shyam Narain.

anchor.surface_text: Talebar had two sons Hanuman and Raghu Nandan. Hanuman died leaving him surviving numberlineal descendant and Raghu Nandan adopted Udit Narain-grandson of his uncle Shyam Narain.

facts.text: Suit No. 27 of 1923 instituted in 1923 by Udit Narain and sons of Shyam Narain against descendants of Indra Narain and Chandra Narain for partition of half share in joint family properties.

anchor.surface_text: In 1923 Udit Narain and the sons of Shyam Narain instituted suit No. 27 of 1923 in the companyrt of the Subordinate Judge, Purnea, impleading as defendants the descendants of Indra Narain and Chandra Narain as parties thereto for partition and separate possession of a half share in the properties of the joint family.

facts.text: Bijendra Narain, a minor in 1923, was impleaded as 8th defendant in suit No. 27/1923 by guardian-ad-litem Bidya Narain (4th defendant, uncle). Sons of Bidya: Mode (5), Hari (6), Rajballav (7).

anchor.surface_text: Bijendra Narain, son of Ishwari Narain who was at the date of the suit a minor was impleaded as the 8th defendant, by his guardian-ad-litem Bidya Narain his uncle, who was impleaded as the 4th defendant, Mode Narain, Hari Narain and Rajballav Narain, sons of Bidya Narain, were impleaded as defendants 5, 6 7.

facts.text: Preliminary decree in suit No. 27/1923 passed on July 1924 by consent of parties, admitting adoption of Udit Narain by Raghu Nandan.

anchor.surface_text: A preliminary decree was passed in the suit on July, 1924 by companysent of parties. By paragraph  a  of the decree the adoption of Udit Narain as a son by Raghu Nandan was admitted and it was agreed that Udit Narain was entitled in the property in suit to a fourth share as adopted son of Raghu Nandan, and a twelfth share as heir of his natural father Shyam Narain.

facts.text: Preliminary decree in suit 27/1923 declared family estate still joint except those partitioned in schedule D, to be partitioned by metes and bounds according to defined shares.

anchor.surface_text: The decree further provided. That the parties agree that the family estate is still joint and that the entire family estate except those that have already been partitioned as detailed below in schedule D will be partitioned by metes and bounds  according  to the shares as defined above

facts.text: Final decree in suit No. 27/1923 made on February 15, 1937 dividing properties into three lots: 8 anna to Udit Narain and sons of Shyam Narain, 4 anna to Indra Narain branch, 4 anna to defendants 4 to 8 (Chandra Narain branch).

anchor.surface_text: A decree final was made on February 15, 1937 and the properties of the family were divided in three lots the first lot representing an eight anna share of Udit Narain and the sons of Shyam Narain, the second representing a four anna share of the branch of Indra Narain, and the third a four anna share of defendants 4 to 8 of the branch of Chandra Narain.

facts.text: Bijendra Narain attained majority in 1934.

anchor.surface_text: Bijendra Narain attained the age of majority in 1934, and on July 10, 1942 companymenced the present action for partition of a half share in the properties which were in the possession of Bidya Narain, his sons and grandsons

facts.text: Bijendra Narain learned in 1938 that Bidya Narain and his sons purchased properties with joint family funds in their own names and in name of Bashisht Narain (24th defendant, daughter's son of Bidya Narain).

anchor.surface_text: alleging that he, Bijendra Narain came to learn in 1938 that taking advantage of his minority and inexperience his uncle Bidya Narain and the sons of Bidya Narain had purchased in their own names many properties with the aid of joint family funds and had acquired certain other properties in the name of Bashisht Narain- twentyfourth defendant in the suit , who was daughters son of Bidya Narain

facts.text: In September 1941, panchas attempted settlement; Bidya Narain and sons admitted properties including those in their and Bashisht Narain's names were joint family properties but refused separate share to plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: that in September, 1941 certain respectable residents of the village companysented to lend their good offices to settle the dispute and to act as panchas, that at the meeting before the panchas, Bidya Narain and his sons admitted that the properties held by them including the properties acquired in their names and of Bashisht Narain were joint family estates, but they later demurred to give to the plaintiff a separate share, and hence the suit.

facts.text: Defendants claimed that decree in suit No. 27/1923 ended joint family status between Bijendra Narain and Bidya Narain; parties held as tenants-in-common since, living separately.

anchor.surface_text: They submitted that by the decree in suit No. 27 of 1923 the joint family status between the plaintiff Bijendra Narain and Bidya Narain had companye to an end, that since the decree passed in the earlier suit the parties had been holding the properties as tenants-in-common and number as joint tenants, that the members of the branch of Bidhya Narain were living and carrying on their business separately,

facts.text: Bashisht Narain (24th defendant) claimed properties in his name purchased with his own funds, no concern with other defendants.

anchor.surface_text: Bashisht Narain the 24th defendant submitted that the properties purchased in his name were obtained with the aid of his own funds and that he had numberconcern with the other defendants.

facts.text: Trial Court held no severance of joint status between Bijendra Narain and Bidya Narain by 1923 decree; properties remained joint; entitled to half share in Sch A immovable, half Sch B movable, accounts from 1941.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge held that by the decree in suit No. 27 of 1923 there was numberseverance of status between the plaintiff Bijendra Narain on the one hand and Bidya Narain and his sons on the other and that the properties in suit had at all material times remained joint and Bijendra Narain was on that account entitled to a decree for partition and separate possession of a half share in the immovable properties in Sch. A.

facts.text: High Court agreed with Trial Court, confirmed decree with modification on Sch B movables, remanded for determination.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal, the High Court agreed with the view of the Trial Court on all the questions in dispute, and companyfirmed the decree, subject to a modification about the direction for determination of movable properties described in Sch. B and ordered that the case be remanded for determining the existence or otherwise of the properties mentioned in Sch. B.

facts.text: Supreme Court held estate joint till suit 27/1923; severance between branches but not between Bijendra Narain and Bidya Narain branch as no unequivocal intention; minor represented by uncle Bidya.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the estate held by the four sons of Man Kishun was till the date of institution of suit No. 27 of 1923 joint family estate. ... There is numberevidence of expression of any such intention by Bidya Narain and his sons to divide themselves from Bijendra Narain they made numbersuch claim in the suit. It is true that a companypromise preliminary decree was passed in the suit. But Bijendra Narain was a minor at the date of that decree and was represented in the suit by his uncle Bidya Narain.

facts.text: Properties in name of 24th defendant Bashisht Narain acquired by Bidya Narain with joint family funds, including court auction purchases; s.66 CPC not applicable as claim is joint family property not benami for plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: As found by the Court of First Instance and affirmed by the High Court many items of property were acquired in the name of the twentyfourth defendant by Bidya Narain. Some of these properties were acquired by purchases at companyrt auctions. The Trial Court has held that these properties were acquired with the aid of joint family funds by Bidya Narain and his sons,

facts.text: Rajballav Narain (defendant No.6) died during trial court suit; Mode Narain (def No.1) died during High Court appeal; does not bar decree for accounts against estates.

anchor.surface_text: Finally, it was urged that since defendants Mode Narain and Rajballav Narain had died during the pendency of the proceedings,, the High Court was incompetent to pass a decree for account against their estates. Rajballav who was defendant No. 6 died during the pendency of the suit in the Trial Court and Mode Narain who was, defendant No. 1 in the suit died during the pendency of the appeal in the High Court.

certificate under Art. 133  1  a  of the Constitution arises out of suit No. 17 of 1942 of the file of Subordinate Judge, Purnea, filed by Bijendra Narain son of Ishwari Narain against Mode Narain, Hari Narain and Rajballav Narain, sons of Bidya Narain, and others for a decree for partition and separate possession of a half share in the properties described in schedules A, B C to the plaint.

concepts.unlisted_description: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: In a Hindu undivided family governed by the Mitakshara law, no individual member of that family, while it remains un- divided, can predicate that he has a certain definite share in the property of the family. The rights of the coparceners are defined when there is partition.

concepts.interpretation: Governs Hindu undivided family where no individual member can claim definite share until partition.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: shares and do award one half to the plaintiff Bijendra Narain and the other half to the defendants. The learned Judge negatived the companytention of

concepts.unlisted_description: School of Hindu law applicable to joint family property rights

anchor.surface_text: Partition consists in defining the shares of the coparceners in the joint property actual division of the property by metes and bounds is number necessary to constitute partition. Once the shares are defined, whether by agreement between the parties or otherwise, partition is complete. The parties may thereafter choose to divide the property by metes and bounds, or may continue to live together and enjoy the property in common as before. If they live together, the mode of enjoyment alone remains joint, but number the tenure of the property.

concepts.interpretation: Defining shares completes partition even without physical division; tenure becomes separate though enjoyment may remain joint.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: properties in his possession did number belong to the joint family. He directed that an account be taken of the assets and liabilities of the family

concepts.unlisted_description: Doctrine defining partition as specification of shares in joint family property

anchor.surface_text: Partition may ordinarily be effected by institution of a suit, by submitting the dispute as to division of the properties to arbitrators, by a demand for a share in the properties, or by conduct which evinces an intention to sever the joint family it may also be effected by agreement to divide the property. But in each case the conduct must evidence unequivocally intention to sever the joint family status.

concepts.interpretation: Severance requires unequivocal intention evidenced by conduct; mere specification of shares insufficient without such intention.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: e of status between the plaintiffs of that suit on the one hand and the defendants on the other, but companynsel for the appellants companytended that

concepts.unlisted_label: Unequivocal Intention to Sever Joint Status
concepts.unlisted_description: Principle for severance of joint family status under Hindu law

anchor.surface_text: A Mitakshara family is presumed in law to be a joint family until it is proved that the members have separated. That the coparceners in a joint family can by agreement amongst themselves separate and cease to be a joint family, and on separation are entitled to partition the joint family property amongst themselves, is number well-established law. But the mere fact that the shares of the coparceners have been ascertained does number by itself necessarily lead to an inference that the family had separated.

concepts.interpretation: Joint family presumed until separation proved; share ascertainment alone does not imply separation.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: n. There companyld evidently be numberagreement between Bidya Narain acting in his own personal capacity and acting as a guardian-ad- litem of Bijendr

concepts.unlisted_label: Presumption of Jointness in Mitakshara Family
concepts.unlisted_description: Legal presumption against separation in Hindu joint families

anchor.surface_text: Section 66 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure provides No suit shall be maintained against any person claiming title under a purchase certified by the Court in such manner as may be prescribed on the ground that the purchase was made on behalf of the plaintiff or on behalf of some one through whom the plaintiff claims.

concepts.interpretation: Bars suits claiming court auction purchase was benami for plaintiff; strictly construed; does not bar claims that property was joint family property acquired with joint funds.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: emely cumbersome and would lead to great delay and in some cases to serious injustice. The Trial Court, as we have already observed, on a companysider

concepts.unlisted_description: Prohibits suits against certified court auction purchasers on benami grounds for plaintiff

anchor.surface_text: Transactions which are called benami rea lawful and are number prohibited. When it is alleged that a person in whose name the property is purchased or entered in the public record is number the real owner, the Court may, if the claim is proved, grant relief upholding the claim of the real owner. But s. 66 1 seeks to oust the jurisdiction of the Court to give effect to real as against benami title.

concepts.interpretation: Benami transactions lawful unless barred by statute like s.66 CPC in auction purchases.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: urt, as we have already observed, on a companysideration of the entire evidence and the subsequent companyduct of the parties came to the companyclusi

concepts.unlisted_description: Doctrine allowing real owner to claim against nominal holder

anchor.surface_text: The maxim actio personalis moritur cum persona-a personal action dies with the person-has a limited application. It operates in a limited class of actions ex delicto such as actions for damages for defamation, assault or other personal injuries number causing the death of the party, and in other actions where after the death of the party the relief granted would number be enjoyed or granting it would be nugatory.

concepts.interpretation: Limited to personal torts ex delicto and actions where relief nugatory post-death; does not apply to claims for accounts.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: mily funds in the name of the 24th defendant. Such a claim does number fall within the terms of s. 66 1 . The judg- ment of this companyrt-Addanki Ven

concepts.unlisted_description: Maxim limiting survival of personal actions after death

anchor.surface_text: But a claim for rendition of account is number a personal claim. It is number extinguished because the party who claims an account, or the party who is called upon to account dies. ... Death of the person liable to render an account for property received by him does number therefore affect the liability of his estate.

concepts.interpretation: Claims for accounts survive death and bind the estate; not personal action.

issues.text: whether by the decree in suit No. 27 of 1923 there was severance of status between the plaintiff Bijendra Narain on the one hand and Bidya Narain and his sons on the other

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge held that by the decree in suit No. 27 of 1923 there was no severance of status between the plaintiff Bijendra Narain on the one hand and Bidya Narain and his sons on the other and that the properties in suit had at all material times remained joint and Bijendra Narain was on that account entitled to a decree for partition and separate possession of a half share in the immovable properties in Sch. A.

issues.text: whether the properties which stood in the name of the 24th defendant belonged to the joint family of the parties

anchor.surface_text: We may advert to the issue whether the properties which stood in the name of the 24th defendant belonged to the joint family of the parties. As found by the Court of First Instance and affirmed by the High Court many items of property were acquired in the name of the twentyfourth defendant by Bidya Narain.

issues.text: whether a share in the properties which had been purchased at court auctions can be given to Bijendra Narain because of s. 66 of the Code of Civil Procedure

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants concedes that on the findings recorded by the High Court, in the properties which were acquired by private treaty the plaintiff Bijendra Narain has established his claim to a share, but he contends that a share in the properties which had been purchased at court auctions cannot be given to Bijendra Narain because of s. 66 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

issues.text: whether since defendants Mode Narain and Rajballav Narain had died during the pendency of the proceedings, the High Court was incompetent to pass a decree for account against their estates

anchor.surface_text: Finally, it was urged that since defendants Mode Narain and Rajballav Narain had died during the pendency of the proceedings, the High Court was incompetent to pass a decree for account against their estates. Rajballav who was defendant No. 6 died during the pendency of the suit in the Trial Court and Mode Narain who was, defendant No. 1 in the suit died during the pendency of the appeal in the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Girdhar Narain said that he was maintaining accounts during the period of his management as receiver, and that out of the surplus which remained with him he paid to Bijendra Narain in 1944 Rs. 1,500 for his two anna share. It was claimed that this was strong evidence indicating that Bijendra Narains share was not only specified but was also separated from that of Bidya Narain and his sons.

arguments.claim: Mitakshara law: no definite share until partition; partition by defining shares, but requires unequivocal intent to sever.

anchor.surface_text: In a Hindu undivided family governed by the Mitakshara law, no individual member of that family, while it remains un- divided, can predicate that he has a certain definite share in the property of the family. The rights of the coparceners are defined when there is partition. Partition consists in defining the shares of the coparceners in the joint property actual division of the property by metes and bounds is not necessary to constitute partition.

arguments.claim: Presumption of joint family until separation proved; mere share ascertainment does not imply separation.

anchor.surface_text: A Mitakshara family is presumed in law to be a joint family until it is proved that the members have separated. ... But the mere fact that the shares of the coparceners have been ascertained does not by itself necessarily lead to an inference that the family had separated.

holdings.text: The decree in suit No. 27 of 1923 did not effect severance of joint family status between Bijendra Narain and Bidya Narain and his sons

anchor.surface_text: But severance between the members of the branches inter se may number in the absence of expression of unequivocal intention be inferred. There is numberevidence of expression of any such intention by Bidya Narain and his sons to divide themselves from Bijendra Narain they made numbersuch claim in the suit. It is true that a companypromise preliminary decree was passed in the suit. But Bijendra Narain was a minor at the date of that decree and was represented in the suit by his uncle Bidya Narain. There companyld evidently be numberagreement between Bidya Narain acting in his own personal capacity and acting as a guardian-ad- litem of Bijendra Narain to sever the joint family status. Specification by the decree of the shares of Bidya Narain and his sons on the one hand and of Bijendra Narain on the other, does number by itself companystitute severance of Bidya Narain and his sons from Bijendra Narain. The specification of shares must be read in the companytext of cl.  1  of the decree which directed division of the estate in three lots only.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of unequivocal intention to separate; Bidya Narain as guardian-ad-litem could not sever status against minor's interest; mere specification of shares insufficient without intent, especially when decree provided for three allotments only; presumption of joint family status applies

holdings.text: Properties standing in the name of the 24th defendant belonged to the joint family as they were acquired with joint family funds

anchor.surface_text: We may advert to the issue whether the properties which stood in the name of the 24th defendant belonged to the joint family of the parties. As found by the Court of First Instance and affirmed by the High Court many items of property were acquired in the name of the twentyfourth defendant by Bidya Narain. Some of these properties were acquired by purchases at companyrt auctions. The Trial Court has held that these properties were acquired with the aid of joint family funds by Bidya Narain and his sons, and with that view the High Court agreed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial and High Courts found properties acquired by Bidya Narain using joint family funds; affirmed by Supreme Court; supported by admission before panchas

holdings.text: Section 66(1) CPC does not bar claim to share in court auction properties acquired with joint family funds in name of another family member

anchor.surface_text: But the suit filed by Bijendra Narain is number of that nature. ... Such a claim does number fall within the terms of s. 66(1). The judg- ment of this companyrt-Addanki Venkatasubbaiah v. Chilakamarthi Kotaiah 1  does number assist the case of the appellants. The decision of the case turned on the true interpretation of s. 66 2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Claim is not that purchase was benami for plaintiff or predecessor but that it was joint family property bought with joint funds; s.66(1) strictly construed applies only to benami for plaintiff; distinguished Addanki case under s.66(2)

holdings.text: Decree for rendition of accounts can be passed against estates of deceased defendants Mode Narain and Rajballav Narain

anchor.surface_text: But a claim for rendition of account is number a personal claim. It is number extinguished because the party who claims an account, or the party who is called upon to account dies. ... Death of the person liable to render an account for property received by him does number therefore affect the liability of his estate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Claim for accounts not personal action under actio personalis moritur cum persona which applies only to limited torts ex delicto or nugatory relief post-death; account claims survive and bind estate

holdings.text: Privy Council observations in Palani Ammal correctly state the law on presumption of jointness and effect of mere share specification in Mitakshara families

anchor.surface_text: A Mitakshara family is presumed in law to be a joint family until it is proved that the members have separated. That the coparceners in a joint family can by agreement amongst themselves separate and cease to be a joint family, and on separation are entitled to partition the joint family property amongst themselves, is number well-established law. But the mere fact that the shares of the coparceners have been ascertained does number by itself necessarily lead to an inference that the family had separated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicitly approves PC statement as correct law despite appellant's obiter claim; applies to facts

holdings.text: Plaintiff not required to plead fabrication of defendant's document in plaint; can challenge reliability at trial without amendment

anchor.surface_text: In any event, we are unable to agree with companynsel for the appellants that where the plaintiff sets up a case that a document relied upon by the defendants in support of their case is a fabrication, it is necessary for him either by his original plaint or by amendment therein to formally plead that the document is a fabrication and that unless he does so he is number entitled to ask the Court to try that plea.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No CPC requirement to plead unreliability of opponent's evidence in pleadings; otherwise trials cumbersome; challenge possible at trial stage

precedents.citation: Palani Ammal v. Muthuvenkatacharla Moniagar others 1 ... L.R. 52 I. A. 83.

anchor.surface_text: Palani Ammal v. Muthuvenkatacharla Moniagar others 1  that In companying to a companyclusion that the members of a Mitakshara joint family have or have number separated, there are some principles of law which should be borne in mind when the fact of a separation is denied. A Mitakshara L.R. 52 I. A. 83.

precedents.cited_proposition: Presumption that a Mitakshara family is joint until separation is proved; mere ascertainment of shares of coparceners does not necessarily lead to inference of separation.
precedents.cited_holding: But the mere fact that the shares of the coparceners have been ascertained does not by itself necessarily lead to an inference that the family had separated. There may be reasons other than a contemplated immediate separation for ascertaining what the shares of the coparceners on a separation would be.

anchor.surface_text: But severance between the members of the branches inter se may number in the absence of expression of unequivocal intention be inferred. There is numberevidence of expression of any such intention by Bidya Narain and his sons to divide themselves from Bijendra Narain they made numbersuch claim in the suit. It is true that a companypromise preliminary decree was passed in the suit. But Bijendra Narain was a minor at the date of that decree and was represented in the suit by his uncle Bidya Narain. There companyld evidently be numberagreement between Bidya Narain acting in his own personal capacity and acting as a guardian-ad- litem of Bijendra Narain to sever the joint family status. Specification by the decree of the shares of Bidya Narain and his sons on the one hand and of Bijendra Narain on the other, does number by itself companystitute severance of Bidya Narain and his sons from Bijendra Narain. The specification of shares must be read in the companytext of cl.  1  of the decree which directed division of the estate in three lots only.
The contention raised by the appellants must therefore fail.

anchor.surface_text: We may advert to the issue whether the properties which stood in the name of the 24th defendant belonged to the joint family of the parties. As found by the Court of First Instance and affirmed by the High Court many items of property were acquired in the name of the twentyfourth defendant by Bidya Narain. Some of these properties were acquired by purchases at companyrt auctions. The Trial Court has held that these properties were acquired with the aid of joint family funds by Bidya Narain and his sons, and with that view the High Court agreed.
The contention raised by the appellants must therefore fail.
